title: 107_hr3810
content:
The "Livestock Ownership Fairness Act of 2002" prohibits packers from owning or feeding livestock for an extended period under the Packers and Stockyards Act, 1921. The "Livestock Ownership Fairness Act of 2002" prohibits packers from owning or feeding livestock intended for slaughter for more than 14 days prior to slaughter. This includes arrangements that give packers control over livestock to the extent that the actual producer is no longer materially participating in the farming operation. The "Livestock Ownership Fairness Act of 2002" prohibits packers from owning or feeding livestock intended for slaughter for more than 14 days prior to slaughter. Exceptions include forward contracting arrangements and cooperatives where producers retain control over the livestock until delivery for slaughter. The "Livestock Ownership Fairness Act of 2002" prohibits packers from owning or feeding livestock for more than 14 days before slaughter. The Act also makes it unlawful for packers to conspire with others to violate these regulations. The effective date of the Act is upon enactment, with transition rules for packers already in violation. The "Livestock Ownership Fairness Act of 2002" sets timelines for compliance by packers: 540 days for swine packers and as soon as practicable, but not later than 180 days, for other livestock packers, as determined by the Secretary of Agriculture. TITLE II--AGRICULTURAL ANTITRUST PROVISIONS

SEC. 201. PREMERGER NOTICE REQUIREMENT. Title II of the Agricultural Antitrust Provisions requires premerger notice for the acquisition of livestock, poultry, or agricultural commodities for wholesale resale. The Secretary must publish notices in the Federal Register, accept public comments, and review proposed mergers within 30 days of receiving a notification. Title II of the Agricultural Antitrust Provisions mandates premerger notice for acquisitions of livestock, poultry, or agricultural commodities for wholesale resale. The Secretary reviews proposed acquisitions to assess their impact on prices, market power, and potential for anticompetitive behavior. A report with detailed findings is prepared by the Secretary. The Secretary conducts a review of proposed acquisitions to assess their impact on competition and market power. A report with detailed findings and an economic analysis is transmitted to the Office of Special Counsel for Agriculture and published in the Federal Register. The Attorney General will establish an Office of Special Counsel for Agriculture in the Department of Justice to handle agricultural antitrust issues. The Special Counsel for Agriculture can only be appointed after a 30-day public comment period. SEC. 203 of the document provides definitions for key terms used in the title, including "antitrust laws," "basic agricultural commodity," "livestock," "person," "poultry," and "Secretary."
